blurb: Most of America's hungry are native-born, but new immigrants like Hullamatou Ceesay from Gambia struggle too, taking meals wherever they can find them.
Kristin Hahn and her grandmother, Janet Groven, visit a weekly soup kitchen in Charles City, Iowa. 'By the end of the month we have nothing.'

I had tears in my eyes when they said I could come. I’m down to the last of my food so what this means to me and my family is we get to eat for the rest of the month and I don’t have to worry. I can sleep – I haven’t slept because in my head, because I’m so worried about making sure we’re ok.

Terri’s great life suddenly vanished when her job disappeared and she needed help from the food pantry at her local church. Now that she’s back on her feet, she’s a regular volunteer at the pantry that helped stabilize her life.

Unlike a lot of kids, summer is not Iker's favorite time of the year. He misses school – the classes, teachers, and his friends – but he also knows that summer means no free breakfast and lunch, which he normally eats in school.

DeAdra wants a better childhood for her three-year-old son with special needs but can't always put food on the table while caring for him full-time. With her local food pantry, DeAdra is now able to provide healthy food for Dacian and herself.

Mikel's eight years of service in the US Army, including a tour in Iraq, took a significant toll. He suffers from PTSD and is disabled. He tries his best to help the family make ends meet. But he still worries about paying rent, bills, and food for his kids.
